awd_titl_txt: HCC: Medium: A Toolkit to Evaluate the Effect of Multitouch Interaction on the Musculoskeletal System and Design Safe Multitouch Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Some have heralded multi-touch interaction as the technology to drive computing systems into the future.   But as we move towards a world where interaction is based on human body movement that are not well documented or studied, we risk creating technology and systems that may lead to musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs).  This is not a hypothetical but a real danger.  In the past devices such as keyboards have led to MSDs, yet many new systems make no effort to avoid gestures that are known to lead to musculoskeletal disorders or to eliminate gestures that are symptomatic of a patient population.  With multi-touch interfaces currently being considered for adoption by companies and academia, it is now more critical than ever that good design practices incorporating preventive approaches be implemented in the initial stages of product design and development.  In this research, the PI and his interdisciplinary team that includes experts in human-computer interaction, kinesiology and ergonomics will evaluate the effect of multi-touch interaction on the musculoskeletal system and provide mechanisms for developing safe multi-touch systems that involve interactions designed to cause minimal musculoskeletal stress and risk.  Project outcomes will include best practices and standards for interaction that are safe yet allow users to fully benefit from the new levels of immersion that multi-touch interaction affords.  In particular, the PI will develop a toolkit that will allow multi-touch designers to input a gesture movement and evaluate its induced stress in a variety of situations and under different variables.  In addition, the software will allow input of formal definitions of HCI tasks and some choices of gestures, and will suggest a set of suitable gestures for the task based on the given choices.  To achieve these goals, the PI will explore new formal models of human-computer interaction that take multi-touch interaction into account at both the cognitive and psychomotor levels.

Broader Impacts: This research will provide multi-touch interaction researchers with valuable new models and tools that focus not on a particular application area but rather on the generic technique of multi-touch interaction and design.  The new biomechanical models will also contribute to our fundamental understanding of the functioning of our hands.  Project outcomes will be generalizable to other emerging types of input devices, such as the Nintendo Wii remote.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of the project was to provide quantitative data about human interaction with multitouch and gestural human computer interfaces, to assist designers in creating systems that reduce the risk of musculoskeletal disorders. We pursued three primary strategies. First, we conducted basic research on the performance, biomechanics, and motor control of multitouch and gestural interaction. We developed new metrics to measure thumb and finger performance when tapping on touchscreen keyboards. We also measured the performance and forces used during other gestures: swiping in different directions, pinching and stretching. We generated novel and unique data that can be used to guide the design of multitouch interactions with touchscreen computers. These studies have substantial intellectual merit, because they answer fundamental questions about the biomechanics and motor control of the hand when using touchscreen technology. The results have the potential for broad impact through better understanding of hand function, and applying our new understanding to better device design.

Our second objective was to use musculoskeletal modeling to predict muscle loading associated with multitouch tasks. We developed a data-based, musculoskeletal computer model of the hand on a freely-available software platform (OpenSim). Our model of the complete set of finger muscles (both intrinsic and extrinsic) adds to an existing model of the arm (shoulder and elbow). To create a valid model using the quantitative experimental data available, we developed optimization techniques to objectively determine the best muscle attachment points. Using optimization demonstrated that models can be effectively scaled, individualized, or transferred to different software platforms objectively, without requiring subjective estimations of things like muscle attachment points. The intellectual merit of these studies is in the engineering techniques used to objectively create musculoskeletal models from experimental data. We chose to use a non-proprietary, freely-available software platform (OpenSim) to ensure that our efforts have a broad impact. Adding our work to a previously-available model of the arm (elbow and shoulder) results in a full musculoskeletal model of the arm that is freely-available and downloadable to all researchers.

Our third objective was to develop a design “toolkit” that can be used to design interfaces that reduce injury risks. We created a design evaluation tool for data-driven evaluation of potential multitouch interface designs that focuses on tapping with the thumb. The tool allows for specific predictions of thumb performance based on fundamental keyboard parameters such as orientation, size, location, and layout. We are currently working on using the musculoskeletal computer model along with experimental measurements to make specific predictions of muscle loading during tapping and multitouch tasks. Our developments have substantial intellectual merit by creating new, quantitative measures to evaluate finger performance during tapping tasks, and directly implementing these measures in a tool that can be used for interface design. Our experimental findings, analytical advances, and computer models all have the potential for broad impact by contributing to designing multitouch interfaces that increase performance and reduce injury risk during human-touchscreen interaction.

We have made a broad impact on the scientific community by disseminating the results of our research. To date, the project has supported over 16 peer-reviewed scientific publications, and 12 presentations at national and international conferences. We have directly worked with industry collaborators The Office Ergonomics Research Committee (OERC.org) and Microsoft Corporation.
